metadata.title: On adhesive properties of Nano-silica/epoxy bonded single-lap joints

sections.text:
The effects of nano-silica on the adhesive properties of epoxy were systematically studied by single lap-shear tests under quasi-static and cyclic loadings. The adhesives were produced from different amount of nano-silica particles incorporated into diglycidyl ether of bisphenolA (DGEBA) epoxy. Stainless steel plates were chosen as adherends. Quasi-static tests were conducted on single lap-shear joints at ambient, with and without exposure to 100% RH at 60 ℃ for different times. Cyclic fatigue tests were also performed on these bonded joints under tension-tension loading. The fracture surface morphology was examined using scanning electron microscopy (SEM) to identify the failure mechanisms. Compared to neat epoxy, it was found that the adhesive strength is increased by 20% under quasi-static loadings.

Even after hygrothermal treatment, the benefit of having nano-silica in neat epoxy on the adhesive joint strength was retained. In cyclic fatigue, without hygrothermal aging, nanoslica/epoxy adhesives have longer lifetimes than neat epoxy; but after hygrothermal treatment, they have similar lifetimes for given stress amplitudes.

sections.heading: 1 INTRODUCTION
sections.text:
Epoxies have been widely used in many engineering applications including as adhesives for aircraft parts, anti-corrosive coatings in pipes, and underfill in electronic packages among others [1]. However, their moderate strength and low toughness are limiting their use in many situations. Hence, in the bonding and joining of structural components, surface pre-treatments of adherends [2] and incorporation of fillers [3] in the epoxy adhesives are the most common ways to improve the performance. Surface pre-treatments are complicated and often involve chemical reactions which need accurate process control. By contrast, addition of rigid fillers into the adhesive is a simple solution, such as ternary hybrid of Ag [4] and carbon nanotubes [5].
As epoxy-based adhesives are susceptible to moisture, which can lead to plasticization and chemical modification of the epoxy network [6], the effects of moisture and high temperature on adhesive strength have been studied for many years [7]. Kinloch et al. [8,9] found that the loss in adhesive strength was due to the adverse effect of water on the interface and corrosion of the substrate but not on the bulk adhesive properties since macro-voids in the aluminum alloy substrate increased the effective driving force for water penetration and aggregation inside the joints. But, Zani-Deffarges [10] and Bowditch [11] concluded from their studies that both the mechanical properties of the adhesive and the interface of the adhesive and adherend were susceptible to both moisture and high temperature. Degradation of the adherend is also an important factor [12]. Thus, Ref [13] showed that the oxide layer of the steel adherend was peeled off after long exposure in humid and warm environment (100% RH, 50 ℃). Recently, several numerical modeling studies [14,15] were performed to analyze the joint degradation process. It is clear from the above discussions, except a couple of investigations on epoxy-based nanocomposites as adhesives [16,17], most past studies about the effects of hygrothermal treatment on adhesive properties were focused on neat epoxy.
The durability of adhesive joints under cyclic loading is another critical issue and several studies were conducted to examine the fatigue behaviour of adhesive joints [18,19]. Kinloch [9] examined the role of the interphase of aluminum adherend and epoxy adhesive in cyclic fatigue with various surface pretreatments of the aluminum substrate. Thus, pretreatment with

low viscosity primer or chromic acid etching gave increased interface area and reduced local stress concentrations, improving the adhesive joint fatigue resistance. The effect of adhesive thickness on the fatigue behavior of single lap joints with thick adherend was studied in [20]. The results obtained showed that the fatigue life could be improved by decreasing the bondline thickness and eliminating interface failure. The influence of load ratio was also reported in [21], Mall et al. found increased fatigue resistance at higher values of load ratio. Recently, Quaresimin and Ricotta [22–24] did a systematic study on cyclic fatigue of single lap joints by experiment and finite element analysis, which indicated that long overlap length and spew fillet corner geometry improved significantly the fatigue life. However, little work has been reported to-date on cyclic fatigue of epoxy adhesives containing nano- or micro- size fillers.
Surface-modified nano-silica in epoxy resin has been commercially available for the last decade [25]. Our previous studies [26–28] have shown that nano-silica particles can improve Young’s modulus, yield strength and fracture toughness, and increase fatigue lifetimes and decrease crack growth rates of neat epoxy. Herein, lap-shear joints based on epoxy or nanosilica/epoxy as adhesive and stainless steel as adherends are prepared and tested. We measure the adhesive strength under quasi-static loading when the joints are dried and after hygrothermal treatment in 100% relative humidity at an elevated temperature of 60 ℃ to assess the hygrothermal effect. Dynamic-mechanical tests are also conducted to evaluate the influence of hygrothermal ageing on the adhesive joints. Also, the effect of cyclic loading on adhesive strength is studied. The fracture surfaces of the adhesive joints after all mechanical tests are finally examined by using scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and energy-dispersive X-ray (EDAX) spectroscopy.

sections.heading: 2.1 Sample preparation
sections.text:
Epoxy resin, Araldite F, bisphenol A diglycidyl ether (DGEBA), and hardener, Piperidine, cycloaliphatic secondary amine, were supplied by Sigma-Aldrich, Australia. Nano-silica particles in master batches with 40 wt.% concentration in DGEBA resin, Nanopox F400, were obtained from Evonik Hanse GmbH, Germany. These surface modified spherical silica particles were formed in situ through sol-gel processing within the resin, yielding an average size of 20 nm and a very narrow particle size distribution which would not change during further blending. Modifications on silica surface enabled crosslinking with epoxy resin during curing and prevented agglomeration in the matrix. Some basic properties of Araldite F and Nanopox F 400 are listed in Table 1.

By mixing plain DGEBA resin with required amounts of nano-silica master batch, epoxybased composites with different filler loading could be obtained. The amount of curing agent was calculated to ensure the weight ratio with epoxy was 1:20. Plain epoxy resin and nanosilica master batches were heated up to 80 ℃ to reduce the viscosity and thoroughly mixed by mechanical stirring. These samples were degassed in vacuum at -100 kPa and 80 ℃ for 4 h to remove traces of humidity and air bubbles. The curing agent was added while stirring slowly after evacuation. The mixture was then used as an adhesive for bonding the tensile single lapshear joints or cast in a rubber mould for the bulk cuboids samples, ensuring no air bubbles inside the mixture. The samples were subsequently cured at 120 ℃ for 16-22 h, after which, they were allowed to cool in the oven to ambient temperature. These preparation procedures were identical to our previous study on the toughening of nano-silica/epoxy [26]. Observation under transmission electron microscopy (TEM) confirmed the nanoparticles were distributed homogeneously in the epoxy matrix at all loading. Four material systems for single lap-shear testing were prepared: (a) neat epoxy (E); (b) 10 wt.% nano-silica/epoxy (S10); (c) 20 wt.% nano-silica/epoxy (S20); and (d) 40 wt.% nano-silica/epoxy (S40).

sections.heading: 2.2 Measurements of adhesive properties
sections.text:
Many test standards exist for characterizing adhesives and their bonding strengths. One commonly used method is the tensile single lap-shear test, which is easy to conduct and resemble closely the type of loading in structural adhesives during service. Here, we followed the single lap-shear test standard ISO 4587-1979. The specimen geometry for the tensile lapshear test is shown in Fig. 1. Stainless steel plates (25×100 mm 2 ) were chosen as adherends owing to their high modulus and strength compared to the nano-silica/epoxy adhesives. They were cut from the same steel sheet in order to maintain same chemical and physical surface properties, ultrasonically cleaned and dipped in acetone for 24 h, washed with distilled water and dried. Two steel plates were adhesively bonded for an overlapped area of 12.5×25 mm 2 .
The thickness of the adhesive layer was ~0.28 mm, which was controlled by inserting short copper wires of the same diameter inside the bonded area. The length and amount of copper wires used did not affect the adhesive property (see red arrows in Fig. 4(a)).
Quasi-static tensile single lap-shear tests were performed on an Instron 3366 machine with a 10 kN load cell at ambient conditions. All test specimens were located symmetrically in the grips; the long axis of the specimens coincided with the direction of the applied force through the centerline of the grip assembly. The load was applied at a constant rate of 1.0 mm/min and a typical load-displacement record of a tensile lap-shear test is shown in Fig. 2. Lap-shear strength was calculated by dividing the fracture load with the bonded area. At least 5 similar tests were conducted and the average result was reported for each individual group.

Single lap-shear joints were exposed to 100% RH at 60 ℃ in an environmental chamber for different periods up to 3 weeks, dried for 24 h at 60 ℃ and tested at ambient to determine the residual adhesive strengths after the hygrothermal treatment.
Load-controlled tension-tension fatigue tests with stress ratio of 0.10 were conducted on single lap-shear samples in an Instron 8800 testing machine. The maximum cyclic stress used varied from 0.3 to 0.8 of the quasi-static failure strength. All cyclic tests were conducted at 1 Hz with a sinusoidal waveform.

sections.heading: 2.3 Characterization
sections.text:
To study the hygrothermal effect on the adhesives layer, bulk specimens (6×2×20 mm 3 ) of adhesive materials, E, S10 and S20, were dried at 80 ℃ in a vacuum oven for 48 h to get rid of any moisture, then exposed to 100% RH at 60 ℃ in a closed chamber until saturated, and were finally placed at 60 ℃ in an oven for desorption until no further weight change was recorded. The thermo-mechanical characteristics of these bulk specimens with and without hygrothermal treatment were tested by dynamic mechanical analysis (DMA, TA2980) at 1 Hz under single cantilever mode at a heating rate 2 ℃/min from 35 ℃ to 155 ℃. The storage modulus E’ and loss factor tan δ values were recorded during the test. The glass transition temperature (Tg) was defined as the temperature at the peak of the energy dissipation tan δ curve. By assuming the damping of the nano-silica particles is negligible, the interface strength indicator, b, can be estimated by [29,30]:
b = (1 – tan δc /tan δm)/Vf (1)
where subscripts c and m refer to composite and matrix, respectively. The volume fraction Vf for S10 and S20 are 6.2% and 12.9%, respectively. A higher value of the parameter b means stronger interfacial interactions.
Field emission scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Zeiss UL TRA Plus) combined with energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (Oxford Instruments Aztec integrated EDX) was used to examine the failure surfaces to study the mode of failure. EDX data were obtained from an area of approximately 120×160 μm 2 and the resolution was about 1.5 μm in depth.

Due to the thermal expansion coefficient (CTE) mismatch between the steel adherend and the adhesive layer, residual thermal stresses were produced as the bonded joints cooled down from curing at 120 ℃ to ambient at 20 ℃ [33]. The CTEs of steel, E, S10, S20 and S40 obtained from thermo-mechanical tests (TMA Rigaku 8140) are 10.8E-6, 70.8E-6, 67.2E-6, 58.3E-6 and 57.1E-6 /K, respectively. Finite element analysis (FEA) using ABAQUS 6.13 gives the average residual thermal shear stress along the adherend/adhesive interface as 0.55, 0.57, 0.53 and 0.73 MPa for E, S10, S20 and S40, respectively. Compared to the adhesive strength measured, the residual thermal stress influence is negligible. Similar results and conclusions were obtained by Liu et al. [34] using Raman spectroscopy.

Fig. 4a shows typical failure surfaces of a sample after the tensile lap-shear test. Owing to the high stress concentration at the edges of the adhesive layer [35], cracks initiate from both ends and grow towards the middle leading to final failure, Fig. 4b. To investigate the failure mechanisms of neat epoxy and nano-silica/epoxy bonded joints, crack initiation sites on the paired or matching failure surfaces (see red circled areas in Fig. 4a) were observed by SEM and EDX. We take S10 as representative of the nano-silica/epoxy adhesive joints. Figure 5 shows paired SEM images of the failed joints, E and S10, where the shear direction is from left to right. No Fe or Cr elements are detected in the EDX element mapping results, which reveal that the fracture did not occur in the adherend. Several comments can be made: (a) Fig. 5f shows the morphology of the steel adherend (without adhesive) with surface cracks or crevices into which the adhesives can penetrate. (b) There are clear differences between these two bonded joints. The failure surface of S10 (Fig. 5c) is much rougher than E (Fig. 5a), which reflects the much more intense plastic deformation of S10 compared to E. (c) From the paired SEM images of S10 we can identify major failure mechanisms. Fig. 5c shows highly deformed ridges of S10 adhesive peeled away from the surface cracks/crevices of the steel adherend leaving behind the broken parts on the paired side in Fig. 5d. This is aided by the high peeling stresses at the fracture initiation sites. Also, debonding/pullout of nano-silica particles can be seen in Fig. 5e for S10. All these deformation mechanisms dissipate large amounts of energy [36], leading to higher adhesive joint failure strength. Fig. 5d exhibits a thin layer of S10 adhesive on the fracture surface indicating the joint fails cohesively. (d) It is obvious that in E the paired SEM images, Figs. 5a and 5b, show matching failure features with epoxy peeled from the surface cracks/crevices of the steel substrate. By comparing Figs. 5b and 5f and noting the different surface characteristics it seems that a very thin layer of E adhesive is present in Fig. 5b suggesting cohesive failure near the interface has occurred. Nonetheless, some regions of adhesive failure (see red arrows) can also be observed. Further work is required to clarify this.

sections.heading: 3.3 Hygrothermal effect on residual adhesive strength of lap-shear joints
sections.text:
The residual strengths of hygrothermally treated adhesive joints, E, S10 and S20, were measured at ambient conditions and the results are shown in Fig. 6. Clearly, the adhesive joint strength decreases with increasing exposure time with a remarkable drop in the first week. After three weeks, the average joint strengths are 11.3, 12.6 and 12.9 MPa for E, S10 and S20, respectively. For all exposure durations, nano-silica/epoxy adhesives outperform neat epoxy adhesive after hygrothermal treatment. Previous study [37] showed an adhesive layer with a thickness of 0.12 mm could not achieve full saturation even after 182 days in water at 50 o C. This result helps explain the fast degradation of the residual adhesive strength after the first week and slow degradation in the next two weeks as shown in Fig. 6.

As given in Table 2, after hygrothermal treatment, both E’ and Tg values of E, S10 and S20 are increased. Also, S10 and S20 showed much larger increments than E. Aging test at 60 ℃ (dried) without moisture for the same duration shows that temperature has little effect on the thermo-mechanical properties for E, S10 and S20. As explained in [39,40], depending on the number of hydrogen bonds formed between the absorbed water molecules and the resin, the water molecules in the composite can be classified into two types, Type I and Type II. In Type I, there is a single hydrogen bond between a water molecule and an epoxy molecule, which affects the epoxy in the form of plasticization and swelling. But in Type II, multiple hydrogen bonds are formed between water and epoxy, promoting secondary crosslinking with the hydrophilic group in the epoxy network. Also, the activation energy to absorb and desorb in Type II is much higher than that in Type I [41]. The improved E’ and Tg of epoxy sample reveals that some Type II bonded water molecules occur after hygrothermal treatment. Since nano-silica particles were surface-modified with hydroxyl groups [42], the water molecules absorbed on the nano-silica surface enhance the bridging between structural segments in the epoxy matrix. Furthermore, the above statement can also be confirmed by the increased interfacial strength indicator b. The results from the thermo-mechanical tests reveal that the beneficial effect of nano-silica particles is maintained after hygrothermal treatment.
The failed joints after hygrothermal treatment for E and S10 were examined by SEM and EDX, and paired SEM images and EDX results are shown in Fig. 8. EDX element mapping results reveal that failure did not occur in the adherend. Several observations are given below: (a) Hygrothermal ageing has smoothed the failure surfaces compared to those without ageing. Clear evidences are found from the surface morphologies of Figs. 8a vs 5a for E and Figs. 8c vs 5c for S10. (b) The sharp ridges of S10 adhesive peeled from the cracks and crevices of the steel adherend in Fig. 5c are much less prominent in Fig. 8c. Also, unlike in Fig. 5e, within the ridges in an area identified by a blue arrow, no debonding/pullout of nano-silica particles can be found, which indicates improved interfacial strength between nano-silica and epoxy after hygrothermal treatment. (c) Comparing the paired SEM images of S10 (Figs. 8c, d), joint failure is mainly cohesive with few visible adhesively failed areas (see red arrows in Fig. 8d). By contrast, in case of E, Fig. 8b does not show the presence of neat epoxy adhesive on the failed surface but resembles the steel surface in Fig. 5f. This indicates dominant adhesive failure in E due to an adverse hygrothermal effect. From the joint strength and failure mode, it can be inferred that the adherend/adhesive interface strength of S10 is stronger than E. The losses in adhesive strength after hygrothermal treatment for E and S10 are due to the degradation of the adherend/adhesive interface and the adhesive material, respectively.

sections.heading: 3.4 Effect of cyclic fatigue on lap-shear joints
sections.text:
Cyclic fatigue test results on single lap-shear joints, E, S10 and S20, were analysed in terms of the applied stress amplitude (σa) vs number of load reversals to failure (Nr) curves. Shenoy et al. [43] mentioned two distinct regions in the σa-Nr curve in cyclic fatigue testing of single-lap joints: the crack initiation dominated region at lower fatigue loads and the crack propagation region at higher fatigue loads. Further, visual microscopic observations from [24] showed that the fraction of the crack initiation phase in the whole fatigue life was in the range of 20% to more than 70% depending on the applied stress level. As suggested by Basquin [44], the relationship between σa and number Nr, is:
σa = σf Nr k (2)

where σf and k are fatigue strength coefficient and exponent, respectively. The number of reversals to failure Nr is related to the number of cycles Nf (Nf >>1):
Nr = 2(Nf – 1) ≈ 2Nf (3)
Figs. 9a and 9b show the log-log plots of experimental results of fatigue tests on “dry” and “wet” single lap-shear joints, E, S10 and S20, respectively. “Wet” means the single lap-shear joints were exposed to 100% RH at 60 ℃ in an environmental chamber for one week before the fatigue test. “Dry” means samples without hygrothermal treatment. From Eq. 2, σf and k can be determined. Hence, before hygrothermal treatment, (σf, k) are (20.76, -0.110) for E, (26.84, -0.108) for S10 and (19.89, -0.074) for S20. Clearly, S10 and S20 have much longer lifetimes than E under the same applied cyclic maximum stress. However, after hygrothermal treatment, the lifetimes of E is comparable with those of S10 and S20.
The failed joints after cyclic fatigue were also examined by SEM. Since cyclic loading changes continuously the fracture surface morphology with number of load reversals (Nr) and crack initiation/growth, it is more practical to focus on the failure surface of each sample after it is broken at similar applied stress amplitude σa. We illustrate in Fig. 10 the failure surfaces near the fracture initiation areas of E and S10 with and without hygrothermal treatment. First, it can be observed that the fracture surfaces of “dry” samples, E (Fig. 10a) and S10 (Fig. 10b) after cyclic fatigue (σa = 8 MPa) show similar features as the “wet” samples, E (Fig. 8b) and S10 (Fig. 8d), under static loading. That is, the joint failure of S10 is mainly cohesive with a few visible adhesively failed areas, and E is adhesive failure. Addition of nano-silica particles in neat epoxy increases the fatigue lifetimes (see Fig. 9a). Second, there is little difference between the surface morphology of “wet” samples of E (Fig. 10c) and S10 (Fig. 10d) after cyclic fatigue failure (σa = 8.9 MPa). This corroborates their similar lifetimes (see Fig. 9b). Striations (0.3-0.4 μm) can be found on the fatigued surfaces of “wet” E and S10 samples.

sections.heading: 4 CONCLUSION
sections.text:
This study has systematically investigated the adhesive properties of single lap-shear joints bonded by epoxy and nano-silica/epoxy at ambient conditions under quasi-static loading, including the influence of hygrothermal exposure to 100% RH at 60 o C, and cyclic loading. Incorporation of 10 and 20 wt.% of nano-silica into epoxy matrix improved the adhesive joint strength by 20%. Even after hygrothermal treatment, the benefit of having nano-silica in neat epoxy on adhesive joint strength was retained. Also, the results obtained indicated that aging of the adherend/adhesive interface and bulk adhesive was the main reason which degraded, respectively, the neat epoxy and silica/epoxy adhesive strength after hygrothermal treatment. In cyclic fatigue, for given applied stress amplitudes, and without hygrothermal ageing, the lap-shear joints with nano-silica/epoxy adhesives displayed longer lifetimes than those with neat epoxy adhesives. When hygrothermally aged, the lap-shear joints showed similar cyclic fatigue lives independent of the adhesives used.

metadata.abstractText: The effects of nano-silica on the adhesive properties of epoxy were systematically studied by single lap-shear tests under quasi-static and cyclic loadings. The adhesives were produced from different amount of nano-silica particles incorporated into diglycidyl ether of bisphenolA (DGEBA) epoxy. Stainless steel plates were chosen as adherends. Quasi-static tests were conducted on single lap-shear joints at ambient, with and without exposure to 100% RH at 60 °C for different times. Cyclic fatigue tests were also performed on these bonded joints under tension-tension loading. The fracture surface morphology was examined using scanning electron microscopy (SEM) to identify the failure mechanisms. Compared to neat epoxy, it was found that the adhesive strength is increased by 20% under quasi-static loadings. AC C EP TE D M AN U SC R IP T ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT Even after hygrothermal treatment, the benefit of having nano-silica in neat epoxy on the adhesive joint strength was retained. In cyclic fatigue, without hygrothermal aging, nanoslica/epoxy adhesives have longer lifetimes than neat epoxy; but after hygrothermal treatment, they have similar lifetimes for given stress amplitudes.
